LEAD: The Senate Banking Committee today approved a $57 billion financing request from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that would continue the savings and loan rescue program through next September.
The Senate Banking Committee today approved a $57 billion financing request from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that would continue the savings and loan rescue program through next September.
The action comes a day after the release of a letter Mr. Brady wrote to Congressional leaders warning that the program would ''virtually cease'' unless Congress provided money before adjourning.

Some $40 billion of the money will be used to cover losses from failed savings and loan institutions. The remaining $17 billion will be used to finance a capital reserve that the Resolution Trust Corporation is required to maintain.
The measure now goes to the full Senate. The House Banking Committee also met today but put off until further notice a vote on additional financing.

The money is in addition to the $50 billion authorized under last year's savings industry rescue. It is also on top of about $60 billion in short-term borrowing, which is to be repaid as regulators sell assets inherited from bankrupt institutions.
The Senate panel also agreed to delete from the proposal a provision that would end the Resolution Funding Corporation's unused borrowing authority.
